title: Before 3 November 2020, will federal legislation curtailing or eliminating qualified immunity for public officials become law?
preds: Such a worthy question and yet no action to report on. It kinda says - to BLM and company - we're just giving you Lip Service. I think a Federal Ins. pool and requiring LEO to carry a policy against eventualities would have been good half measure, but no, we;ll just see a winnowing of the talent pool from which LEO typically comes.

Republicans will lose the presidential elections, and will leave "federal legislation curtailing or eliminating qualified immunity for public officials" as their legacy trojan horse to enable them to bombard the next administration.

If true it may also be expanded and applied to public servants who take part in BLM rallies or similar peaceful protest. Precondition to that is eliminating qualified immunity for public officials, which there will be rumors about next, imho. https://amgreatness.com/2020/09/16/report-ag-barr-pushes-for-sedition-charges-against-violent-rioters/ Further reading in that direction: https://www.kiro7.com/home/ag-barr-asked-federal-prosecutors-explore-criminal-charges-against-seattle-mayor-durkan-over-chop-report-says/IOPUU5GX2JA2DAUQUHVJ2YKUFU/
https://www.i24news.tv/en/news/international/americas/1600320674-us-attorney-general-seeks-charges-for-seattle-mayor-over-autonomous-protest-zone "Seditious conspiracy (18 U.S.C. § 2384) is a crime under United States law. It is stated as follows:     If two or more persons in any State or Territory, or in any place subject to the jurisdiction of the United States, conspire to overthrow, put down, or to destroy by force the Government of the United States, or to levy war against them, or to oppose by force the authority thereof, or by force to prevent, hinder, or delay the execution of any law of the United States, or by force to seize, take, or possess any property of the United States contrary to the authority thereof, they shall each be fined or imprisoned not more than 20 years, or both." https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Seditious_conspiracy
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sedition#Civilian May you live in interesting times.
No way. Election year and senate Rs don’t support.
Holding at 0, still not even begin talked about.
Would take another event. Congress in recess.
Would rather keep all options open to finally capture President Trump.
it will never pass the senate
Mitch McConnell will not allow that
SCOTUS refused to take up qualified immunity. It would take a miracle for this to turn the corner prior to Nov. 3.

Continues to be a non-issue for both divisions of Congress and would likely be vetoed by the President even if it were to pass given the pro-police stance that he has maintained throughout the demonstrations and protests. Virtually impossible for the Senate to override the veto with its current makeup. Maybe on another year when this was the primary issue, but with a pandemic, pending housing crisis, unemployment at record highs, GDP falling by historic amounts, unidentified federal police patrolling the streets in major urban centers, and questions surrounding the security and accessibility of our elections, this just isn't the year for such legislation to be passed.

No chance it gets through the Senate.
No chance it gets signed by the President.
No chance especially with Trump sending federal agents on protests.

There's nothing to believe there's a world that Republican's would entertain this, especially when Trump is running a "law and order" style of campaign. Even if there were many Republicans asking for this, it seems extremely unlikely that McConnell would bring it to a vote. I stayed out of this question originally because I find forecasting the whims of Congress as not a strong suit, but I don't know how to even consider a world in which this would make it out of the senate (and be enough to overrule a presidential veto).

It is not being discussed in the Senate-run GOP, and were it to be brought to a vote, it would definitely be shot down by Republicans anxious to please their base. It would be a pipe-dream to suggest this could happen in the next three months, especially with a nationwide pandemic happening. If anything, it may get challenged in the Supreme Court, but legislation is almost impossible in that time frame.
Yeah, I'm not confident in this happening either.
in an election year political gridlock and polarization will prevent any progress
Campaign issue, but voting will be problematic prior to an election.  Rump Congress will pass something.
No, the Republican Senate will not pass this
Not likely at least until the balance of power shifts.
Conservatives will continue to oppose and thwart any attempt to reduce protection for public officials
The current laws will remain. They are well tested in the courts. Also, without their protections literally no one would choose to become a LEO.

Let’s begin by establishing some basic assumptions. A ridiculously small 1 percent of bills introduced in Congress become law. That’s out of the 13,778 pieces of legislation introduced in the current 119th Congress according to GovTrack. [1] There are currently two proposed solutions to the qualified immunity issue before Congress, one of these has entered the legislative process and was passed by the House after being introduced on June 8. [2][3]  In a perfect world scenario, the bill would become law on February 24, 2021. This accounts for the average of 263.57 days between introduction and signing. [4] But we know this is not a perfect world. Despite the groundswell campaign to end qualified immunity, it is unlikely that a Republican-controlled Senate will pass such a bill. Especially originating from a Democrat controlled House. Even if this was to happen, the President has expressed strong, unwavering support for the police which leaves in grave doubt that he would ever sign such a measure. [5]  Should the possibility of veto override be raised, Congress has only succeeded in doing that in 7.1 percent where that option was available, making the odds at 13:1.[6] Considering all the evidence, I am assigning a 1 percent probability at this point.  [1] https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/statistics
[2] https://crsreports.congress.gov/product/pdf/LSB/LSB10492
[3] https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/7120/actions
[4] https://www.quora.com/How-long-does-it-take-to-pass-a-bill-in-the-US
[5] https://www.politico.com/news/2020/07/10/trump-defund-the-police-fad-356442
[6] https://www.archives.gov/files/legislative/resources/education/veto/veto-procedure.pdf (See note accompanying Table 1 on page 2)
I do not believe that the populace favors more immunity for those in position of power.
I initially had only a low probability, and with time passing and no fundamentals changing, I'm adjusting my estimate down to 0.

Trump seem to have made BLM and other protests one of his main targets in his presidential campaign. Which is also in line with his base. Have an extremely hard time seeing him not vetoing any legislation which is perceived to have its origin from or be in line with BLM protests.
Disregarding Trump there also seem to be a pretty clear split between democrats and republicans on this issue and with an election year signalling to voters is more important than finding compromises.

The horizon for the change is too short. Even if it were an election-winning issue, the local-nature of political battles in Senate and House races would most likely make this a forward promise. The Fall legislative calendar will be a bare cupboard.
Seems impossible given the composition of the congress and the fact that they've resisted to this point.
House only 50% likely to pass it times Senate 3 and President (in lockstep) only 5% = 3%
Republicans will let any bill die in the Senate.

Curtailment - is possible and could be discussed
Elimination - not possible ATM because it would hinder public officials from performing their duties But the timeline (Nov 3) is short and it is tough to pass such contentious legislation in a situation such as the USA finds itself in currently.  So baseline estimate at 5%.

If the bill that passed the House [1], somehow passed the Senate, it would most certainly be vetoed by Trump, and I don't think the votes would be there in the Senate to override the veto. [1] https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2020/06/25/george-floyd-house-approve-sweeping-police-reforms-banning-chokeholds/3251990001/
Well this turned into another Badminton birdy all to fast.

With Scott's bill not including this measure, Democrats pledging to vote against it rather than modify it, and McConnell not airing the house bill (which does include this measure), I'm loweing my estimate. 
In particular I estimated republican voter and senator support at at 40% and 80% (conditioned on other things), but the developments above lower both of those by at least half each.

BLM protests seem to have gone quiet and since the only reason I saw for republicans budging on the issue (especially an election year) was continues street protests I'm readjusting my probability forecast down from 5% to 1%.
There is no reason for Republicans to pass such legislation. It will turn off a majority of their base.

Republicans really have no incentive to pass controversial legislation at this point. I think they're just trying to avoid any votes that could upset supporters. I think nationally Mcconnell just won't let this come to a vote.

Resistance from Senate Republicans and especially from Trump seems likely to stop any effort to eliminate qualified immunity, but it does seem like curtailing qualified Immunity is on the table as part of negotiating other reforms.

It doesn't matter what the public support for this legislation is. It doesn't even really matter what Republican support for it is. Right now, there seems to be a Republican divide in Congress on whether to change it or leave it as is, but there does not seem to be an appetite to get rid of it. If Republican senators feel political pressure from their constituents to do something about qualified immunity, they can say that they support curtailing it and be comfortable in the fact that the majority leader will likely never bring  it to the floor to force them to actually vote that way, preserving their ability to play both sides down the road. I gave it 5% though because if these past four years has taught me nothing, it's that there's still an outside chance something truly crazy and unforeseen could happen.

A criminal justice reform bill has already been passed by congress and signed by president Trump during this presidential term. It was lobbied for by insiders and by Senate Republicans. Those forces could possibly be brought to bear again if popular opinion supported police reform. Reforming qualified immunity is not even being polled on widely in this current debate, however. I take that as a sign that this particular reform is unlikely to be among reforms proposed by Republicans. Finally, Trump himself has both spoken and acted on the "pro-police" side of the issue, meaning he may oppose any legislation that could be characterized as "anti-police" that Congress supports, including this one.
Majority public support for this particular reform: 40%. Republican voter support given that: 50%. Timely congressional Republican support given that: 80% (only takes a few senators, but need cloture). Trump support given that: 60%. Total: 6%.
It’s happening in the states ... but in the end I bet gop blocks meaningful reform
Time frame for debate seems too short. It will most likely occur after Nov 3rd.

This is tricky because there are two bills and only the Democratic one addresses qualified immunity. Chance of this changes rests on the GOP bill being dropped and winning GOP votes in the Senate OR on the GOP bill being amended, which is not impossible. Remember this congress did reach an agreement on criminal justice reform and provided there isn't a filibuster the Dems only need 4 GOP senators and some like Romney and Tim Scott would probably already vote for the dem bill.
The Senate of November 3, 2020 would never pass it.
This is still volatile with quite a way until November, despite the challenges proponents face.
The Republicans will not support it. Likely to pass the house but be blocked in the senate.
Virtually zero chance of Congress moving to eliminate this law and a very low probability that it will be amended in any fashion whatsoever.
Not during this administration.  It could pass the house, theoretically, but the senate would shut it down.

We remain in a stage of consequence and public backlash.  Unless more murders occur at the hands of the police, curtailing or eliminating qualified immunity is not going to be the pressing issue for next five months.
Topic is too controversial and public is too divided on the issue for this to become law in the run-up to the election.
The current administration has proven time and again they have no interest in doing anything right or reasonable
Republicans and police groups are against it.
Lack of political will to do this.
Although this is the most effective approach to preventing police excessive force, legislatures at every level are too scared of appearing "soft on crime" to quash qualified immunity.
Federal legislation eliminating qualified immunity for public officials won't be passed because the Republicans still control the Senate
Nothing will get done on this until after the elections. Dems will say “we tried” Reps will say, “we didn’t backdown.”
Too much opposition at every level of Congress and the White House.
It may pass in the House, but McConnell will sit on it, like all the other bills. Even if McConnell allowed a vote, it would not pass the Senate.
Passing a contending legislature is hard, especially in an election year and with less than 5 months to go.
Not as long as Mitch McConnell is in his position.
it would have to pass the senate and that is not going to happen before Nov 3rd

It's not in the Senate bill, and The Great And Powerful Oz says he'll veto a bill that contains it.  In the interest of something rather than nothing, the House will eventually scrap the provision.  States can of course remove this protection for state-level offenses, and some will.
Trump can't survive without a scared base that thinks they must rely on him for law and order.  He won't undercut that.

Qualified immunity is an absolute nightmare for the Republicans five months prior to the election.   Police are base Republican voters and so are there supporters.   Trump is trying to shave off a enough of Biden's black votes to win several primaries, and McConnell wants to make sure that Republicans win a majority in the next senate.     Voters tend to vote against politicians they do not like rather than for politicians they like.   The Black Lives Matter movement is now a central issue with a lot of support in the coming election.  Republicans will alienate some of their base voters if they support this legislation.   The Republicans will also lose some swing voters if they fight attempts to repeal qualified immunity. Therefore, I suspect Republicans have concluded they can only lose votes in the general election if they support or oppose any legislation on this issue.  There are fewer swing voters than in the past.  Now the emphasis seems to be a lot more on exciting the base in order to increase turnout.  Carl Rove was famous choosing – and winning—W. Bush’s elections with this approach rather than trying to reach swing voters.   This has also been Trump’s approach.  There are other powerful groups that want to keep qualified immunity who have not been discussed in the media.  I am a lawyer who worked as a criminal lawyer and as an insurance defense lawyer for many years.  States, cities and counties can insure for liability arising out of the use of excessive force resulting from negligent supervision and hiring in addition to federal civil rights statutes.   The insurance companies are a key source of funds for Republicans and a few Democrats.  They do not want to payout large awards.  Also, states, city and county governments do not want to pay higher premiums.    I believe insurance companies, states, cities and counties will have greater pull should their interests conflict with the officers' interests.  Qualified immunity is something I believe the average person would find ridiculous in its current form.  Namely,  in order for a police officer, sheriff’s deputy, correctional officer, etc.,  to be found liable for using excessive force there has to be a pre-existing court decision stating the act of the officer constituted excessive force in nearly identical circumstances.   The Supreme Court in 2006 decided the officers had to have notice that a specific application of force was excessive before the officer could be liable.   It does not matter how obvious the application of force was excessive, if there is no case on point, the notice requirement has not been met.   The courts have also been very narrowly interpreting past cases to make sure they do not apply to the current case before the court.    This has turned a two step process: Was excessive force used? And, Is there a case on point?  into a one step process: Is there a case with an identical application of excessive force under identical circumstances?  The answer is almost always no.  Fortunately, there are some very conservative politicians, including Justice Clarence Thomas, who have a problem with qualified immunity as it currently exists.  Yet, police and their conservative supporters oppose the elimination and even the curtailing of qualified immunity.  The key is the word "curtailing."  I really doubt there will be enough Republican senate votes to eliminate qualified immunity. In order for qualified immunity to be "curtailed," whatever that means, several things must happen. 1) Curtailment legislation must pass the house.  This will happen because there are more than enough democrats to make that happen. 2) Curtailment legislation must pass the senate.   a) Right now the senate is 53 to 45, Republicans over Democrats.  There are two independents who caucus with the Democrats so it is really 53 Republicans  to 47 Democrats.       b) McConnell wants to keep his majority.  There are 33 senators running for six-year regular terms and two special elections so there will be 35 senate elections.  Twenty-three of these seats are held by Republicans and twelve by Democrats.  To keep control, McConnell can only lose three seats if Trump is re-elected and only two seats if Trump loses because a Democratic VP would vote in case of a tie.   All but eight Republican seats are considered safe, and the Alabama seat will certainly go to a Republican.  Therefore, McConnell needs at least five of the remaining eight Republican senators who are in tight races to keep control of the senate.   Three or four  Republicans in the current session will also have to vote in favor of any bill for it to pass, depending upon how Pence votes.  Moreover, thirteen Republicans will have to vote in favor of cutting off debate inorder to hold a vote.   Susan Collins, Martha McSally, Cory Gardner, Thom Tillis, Mitch McConnell, Joni Earnst, Kelly Loeffler, and Steve Daines are considered at risk.  There is also an open seat in  Kansas.   Based upon a quick review Collins, McSally, Loeffler, Gardner and Daines are far too far behind in the polls to have more than an outside chance of being re-elected.  However, the Republicans will win Alabama.  Therefore, it can be assumed that at best, the senate will have 49 Republican seats in the next session absent something very unusual.   In the remaining seats, Iowa, Kansas,  and Montana have very few African American voters.  The political culture in these states is also strongly Republican.   Kentucky is only about 8 percent African American and 86 percent white.   The African American vote might make a difference in Kentucky because the polls are so close.  Thus, the only Republican senators in a close contest with a large enough African American population to influence the outcome are Thom Tillis and Mitch McConnell. Tillis has expressed a willingness to eliminate qualified immunity.  In fact, I read some of his positions on race, which are unusual for a Republican.  He supports Black Lives Matter, anti-lynching bills and as speaker of the North Carolina house -- passed reparations for victims of North Carolina's eugenics program.   He is a Republican who will bend with the wind.    McConnell leads his opponent by one point.   However, McConnell is always unpopular in Kentucky, and he has won every senate race since 1984.   He also has the entire senate to worry about.  Senators Romney and Murkowski have also expressed some interest in supporting Black Lives Matter.   Yet, only Rand Paul and Thom Tillis have expressed any interest in “addressing” qualified immunity.   c) In order to pass the senate the bill must be approved by committee and then pass the full chamber.   A bill can pass the full chamber by unanimous consent, a voice vote or a recorded vote.  Of course, debate has to be terminated by a vote of 60 senators in order for any of the above to occur.   Finally, McConnell sets the calendar and can refuse to schedule a vote on any house bill.  I think the experience in the anti-lynching bill a few weeks ago is instructive.  The senate tried to pass a very uncontroversial antilynching bill by unanimous consent.  This would have had the effect of making every senator in favor of this bill, without a recorded vote.   One senator, Rand Paul, voted no.  I doubt he believes his stated reasons.  I think he is just trying to spare his party and Trump from taking  a position on an unpopular position with their base—and potentially reducing Republican turnout.   Namely, he opposed the bill so other senators would not have to vote on it and -- more importantly-- so Trump would not have to sign it.     The senate could have scheduled a recorded vote but did not.  McConnell said it was tor two reasons: It would take too much time from other matters, and Rand Paul could still be convinced.  To me this is putting the best face on a refusal to pass a bill popular with the general public but unpopular with the base.  Why would the senate Republicans do such a thing?  As stated above, to make sure the base Trump voters (Hilary’s “deplorables,” i.e., racists)  are excited enough to turn out and vote.   Donald Trump has never in more than three years denounced white supremacists.  I will not spell out the reasons because they are many and anyone who regularly watches the news will already knows.  Well, one example: "There were good people on both sides,"  when in Charlottesville the white supremacists marched and a anti-white supremacist protester was murdered.  I think  Trump and perhaps several senators did not want to be put on the record and Paul, who was not up for election, stopped it.  I think it unlikely that a bill curtailing qualified immunity will emerge from the senate. Trump will not want to be put in the position of vetoing or signing the bill, and he will not want to force Tillis and himself to go on the record.  McConnell has a history of protecting vulnerable senators from making unpopular votes in their states, e.g., Susan Collins during impeachment.   3)  Trump does not want to alienate those white supremacists he refuses to criticize.   He also does not want to alienate police.   Trump has always had a "base strategy."   And, his base includes deplorables who are fine with cops killing African Americans without consequences.   4)  Yet, the Black Lives Matter movement has acquired a lot of momentum.  Many years ago I read a book by Dick Morris who was a campaign strategist who helped win many close races for Bill Clinton, including the White House.  He said every so often a political issue becomes so popular it is like a cannon going off.  Once the cannon ball is in the air travelling at hundreds of miles per hour, that energy must be expended.  If you get in its way, you will be bowled over.  However, you can deflect the cannon ball's direction or even change its trajectory.  Sometimes, you can even change the trajectory enough that it destroys your political opponent who fired the cannon at you.  I understand the above is now dogma for all political consultants. In this case, I the Republicans will try to expend the energy by introducing a bill more to the liking of their base.  They have the only black Republican Senator very publicly working on an alternative to curtailing or ending qualified immunity, which he says is a non-starter.  
No doubt the Republicans are polling their base as we speak to see what  their base will find acceptable. For example,  Republicans  could eliminate choke holds, require better background checks of police, or they could require a database keeping track of incidents of excessive force and forbid the hiring of cops who were fired from another department.  This way the Republicans can protect their base voters: police officers, other pro-law enforcement types, insurance companies, state, city and county officials in red states—and the deplorables.  I suspect an alternative bill is far more likely than eliminating or curtailing qualified immunity prior to the election.

The American people do not want to give politicians a free pass to break the laws of our country for their personal advantage. This is USA, not Russia. Qualified immunity is a crime and has no place in our democracy. Our political system is corrupt and needs this change, but sadly it will not become law anytime soon.
Trump and the Senate are still Republicans
Anything is possible, but maybe not this.

I think there is a great deal of sentiment to produce this legislation, but President Trump has made it clear he will not support this. This is red meat to his base. McConnell has not challenged the President on this at all and he has the ability to stall this in the Senate until the elections.
Difficult to change laws that protect governmental efforts.  Runs counter to republican controlled senate interests.

Trump wants to run as a law and order candidate and therefore will not approve legislation curtailing or eliminating qualified immunity for public officials, nor will Mitch McConnell allow such legislation to even come up for a vote.
Trump will veto any legislation that is not aligned with his authoritarian world view. Even Kanye and Kim won’t be able to get him on board.
The question is so politically divisive and Congress is so polarized that the republican senate majority and the president will view the proposal as undermining law and order.

Qualified immunity allows public officials to act for the greater good without too much worry of retribution by small disaffected groups. On the other hand it can also be a cover for corruption and this fact may lead to changes in the existing laws. On the third hand it is well established law and  the quid pro quo is always difficult to move in an opposite direction.

Trump will still be in office and his campaign messaging focuses on law and order.  Plus the US Congress takes forever to get anything done.  A bill is likely to pass in the House but won't in the Senate and is therefore unlikely to reach the President's desk.
Dems might pass it in House.  But Senate unlikely too.  And even if they do, the President would veto it. Senate I’ll not have passed it by a large enough margin to override a veto.
I see no mainstream push for such an initiative

Minor change may be made to appease public sentiment and provide cover for politicians.   Core qualified immunity will remain in most cases.  Counter pressure from GOP base and police unions may kill it.

Those voting on it are public officials and people working for government are working for them. In my state one can already sue a public official who does anything outside the scope of their employment.
I do not see Trump signing this into law.
There appears to be enough support to pass it.  Trump will likely veto it because of this clause.  Not sure any new legislation is veto proof with this provision.
Can and should bend to political pressure in order to secure more funding from congress, or for purposes of electioneering.

Something like that should be debated and thought out, not rushed into.  This is where our bicarmel legislature will do what it is built to do, that is, delay the decision and see where sentiment stands in 2021.
Legislation to curtail - a very broad proposition- is likely in next stimulus bill
Not with Trump and Barr in office
Things would have to be veto proof and move unbelievably fast.. seems extremely unlikely in the current environment tight before an election

Does not appear likely at present with a Republican-controlled Senate + Oval Office. The question's 'curtailing' option may set up a small 'yes' possibility.. https://thehill.com/homenews/senate/502179-senate-at-logjam-over-changing-qualified-immunity-for-police https://www.cbsnews.com/news/white-house-reducing-immunity-cops-non-starter/ https://reason.com/2020/06/10/senate-republican-police-reforms-wont-touch-qualified-immunity/
With the current makeup of the Congress, I don't see this happening unless the number of incidents continues to escalate nation-wide.
There is too much at risk just prior to the election

The Supreme Court has repeatedly ruled on this issue, creating and upholding this qualified immunity.  The Congress does not have the internal support to abolish this immunity, nor would the current President sign such legislation.
This seems like the minimum possible bone the Republican Party could toss to black voters ahead of the 2020 presidential election.

Signalling a position of law and order is important from Trump. While Trump hasn't commented directly, his administration has said they are open to discuss everything with regards to police reformation EXCEPT qualified immunity.[1] This being an election year in USA I think both democrats and republicans are more interested in signalling to their respective bases than to actually get something done which I believe will hinder any discussions. Of the 54 cosponsors of the bill in the house only one is republican.[2]
I believe Trump and other high profile republicans are avoiding the issue at the moment because of the protests, but when the protests die down, which I believe they will do in late summer early autumn at the latest, they will push back hard. If the protests continues throughout summer and autumn with equal strength I can see republicans budge. 1. https://www.charlotteobserver.com/news/nation-world/national/article243484141.html
2. https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/7085/cosponsors?searchResultViewType=expanded&KWICView=false
This would put President Trump into risk so it’s unlikely to happen.
The same immunity also shields the very law makers.
There is a lot of pressure in the current climate of unrest.  Tough to get through, but t,here is a possibility.
It has little support in the senate and none from the Trump administration.
They will try, but immunity from crimes is no longer acceptable.
Not enough support in Congress; would need a veto proof majority with current administration.
Police need some level of legal protection to do their jobs.

Very few laws are passed in typical election years.  We only have a few months before the election.  The political climate is highly divided. Mitch McConnell won't let most of the bills passed in the house even get a vote.  If the passed the current president would likely veto it.

Too many people have done things they are not proud of and can be prosecuted for. Imagining that politicians will eliminate what gives them immunity from their ‘skeletons in the closet’, in order to be fair, or get back at their adversaries is highly unlikely and not basic human nature
This is a state issue primarily. The feds aren’t going to relinquish power of Fed LE. Won’t pass Senate.
Federal law requires the signature of the president. Not happening.
Democrats will support it President Trump will not.  So even if it passed the Senate (doubtful), the President will veto it
The vast majority of cops are Trump supporters and Trump's polls are not looking good. He wouldn't risk alienating his most ardent supporters.

It is possible that republican senators in states with a large black population may feel the need to support changes to qualified immunity. With Romney participating in a protest this past weekend there is a small chance that he will support legislation put forward by democrats. The final component is Trump who may be swayed by republican leaders to consider the potential impact it would have on the election cycle.
No. Qualified immunity shielding public officials does not have a chance to be curtailed or eliminated by federal legislation until there is a Democratic majority in both houses of Congress.
I'll follow the line of thinking offered by @Jabaribean on this one. The effort will be made, the result is likely to be the same.
It might pass the House, but it won't pass the Senate.

The "officials" deciding it are the very ones who will be affected by the legislation. It probably will happen, but: it will happen very late, which means 15 October 2020 to 28 October 2020, one of the last initiatives the current administration puts into law.
it will happen, if the Republican party hopelessly succumbs in the presidential elections. In the effect, legislation would be some kind of a burnt-earth-heritage to the next Democratic administration, and a Trojan horse at the same time: not enough time to hold current officials accountable before election, but a signal to the electorate. If installed before the term ends, there will be quite a bit unfriendly fire for the next (Democrat-dominated) Congress and WH administration...

Could pass in the house; unlikely to pass in the Senate--Republicans are in the habitat of being on the side of "law and order" to appeal to their conservative base, also they would be afraid of crossing Trump and his MAGA base; Trump would veto if it did pass to show that he is a tough guy and on the side of tough guys--that has been a consistent trend for him and why he likes dictators and "strong men".  Another consistent trend of his is that he is insensitive to the civil rights of minorities.  His MAGA base would see it as a betrayal if he doesn't veto.
Little chance of any agreement in the Federal House or Senate.
As protest numbers dwindle, and elections come close, "pro law and order" candidates will dig in their heels
